H.text: There is a Ten Commandments monument on the grounds of the Texas Capitol.
H.ref: The cases before the court involve a Ten Commandments monument on the grounds of the Texas Capitol and a display of the commandments in a Kentucky courtroom.

H.text: There is a granite monument of the Ten Commandments outside the Texas capitol building.
H.ref: A 6-foot-tall granite monument of the Ten Commandments outside the Texas capitol building is constitutional, but smaller displays of the Decalogue inside two Kentucky county courthouses must go, the Supreme Court ruled in separate decisions Monday.

H.text: There are displays of the Decalogue inside two Kentucky courthouses.
H.ref: A 6-foot-tall granite monument of the Ten Commandments outside the Texas capitol building is constitutional, but smaller displays of the Decalogue inside two Kentucky county courthouses must go, the Supreme Court ruled in separate decisions Monday.

H.text: The Supreme Court ruled that the monument of the Ten Commandments outside the Texas capitol building is constitutional.
H.ref: A 6-foot-tall granite monument of the Ten Commandments outside the Texas capitol building is constitutional, but smaller displays of the Decalogue inside two Kentucky county courthouses must go, the Supreme Court ruled in separate decisions Monday.

H.text: The Supreme Court ruled that the displays of the Decalogue inside two Kentucky county courthouses must go.
H.ref: A 6-foot-tall granite monument of the Ten Commandments outside the Texas capitol building is constitutional, but smaller displays of the Decalogue inside two Kentucky county courthouses must go, the Supreme Court ruled in separate decisions Monday.

H.text: The Supreme Court ruled that displaying the Ten Commandments on government property does not necessarily violate the Constitution.
H.ref: The Supreme Court ruled Monday that displaying the Ten Commandments on government property does not necessarily violate the constitutional principle that there must be a separation between church and state.

H.text: Demonstrators shouted religious slogans outside the Supreme Court.
H.ref: With demonstrators shouting religious slogans outside, Supreme Court justices questioned, argued and fretted over whether Ten Commandments displays on government property cross the line of separation between church and state.

H.text: Supreme Court justices debated whether Ten Commandments displays on government property cross the line of separation between church and state.
H.ref: With demonstrators shouting religious slogans outside, Supreme Court justices questioned, argued and fretted over whether Ten Commandments displays on government property cross the line of separation between church and state.

H.text: Two cases before the Supreme Court involve Ten Commandments displays in Texas and in Kentucky.
H.ref: The cases before the court involve a Ten Commandments monument on the grounds of the Texas Capitol and a display of the commandments in a Kentucky courtroom.

H.text: The Supreme Court justices usually leave some of the hardest cases for the final month of the term.
H.ref: The Supreme Court justices usually leave some of the hardest cases for the final month of the term, and this year is no different.

H.text: The Rev. Rob Schenck set up a podium and a large wood and marble display of the 10 commandments outside the U.S. Supreme Court.
H.ref: For the third week in a row, the Rev. Rob Schenck set up a podium and a large wood and marble display of the 10 commandments outside the U.S. Supreme Court on Monday, in anticipation that the high court would rule on two cases that challenge displays of the Decalogue on public property.

H.text: The last time the Supreme Court ruled on a Ten Commandments case was in 1980.
H.ref: The last time the Supreme Court ruled on a Ten Commandments case was in 1980, when it invalidated a Kentucky law that required the posting of the Ten Commandments in every public school classroom.

H.text: The Supreme Court invalidated a Kentucky law that required the posting of the Ten Commandments in schools.
H.ref: The last time the Supreme Court ruled on a Ten Commandments case was in 1980, when it invalidated a Kentucky law that required the posting of the Ten Commandments in every public school classroom.

H.text: The US Constitution's First Amendment establishes the principle of separation of church and state.
H.ref: The US Constitution's first amendment establishes the principle of separation of church and state, but how this should be interpreted remains unclear following numerous contradictory decisions by lower courts.

H.text: Christians and Jews believe God handed the Ten Commandments to Moses on Mount Sinai.
H.ref: The more contentious question before the court, legal experts say, is a challenge to the display of framed copies in two Kentucky courthouses of the Ten Commandments, which Christians and Jews believe God handed to Moses on Mount Sinai.

H.text: A suit against the Texas monument was brought by Thomas Van Orden.
H.ref: The suit was brought by Thomas Van Orden, a former lawyer who is now homeless.

H.text: Thomas Van Orden is a former lawyer.
H.ref: The suit was brought by Thomas Van Orden, a former lawyer who is now homeless.

H.text: Thomas Van Orden is now homeless.
H.ref: The suit was brought by Thomas Van Orden, a former lawyer who is now homeless.

H.text: The U.S. Supreme Court heard arguments on whether Ten Commandments displays on government property are compatible with the Constitution.
H.ref: After more than two decades of dodging the question, the U.S. Supreme Court this week heard oral arguments on whether Ten Commandments displays in courthouses and other public space are compatible with the First Amendment to the Constitution.

H.text: Moses is depicted inside the Supreme Court building.
H.ref: "Invocation of the almighty by our public figures, at all levels of government, remains commonplace," Scalia wrote, noting that even inside the Supreme Court building, Moses is depicted holding the Ten Commandments and that court sessions open with a clerk proclaiming "God save the United States and this honorable court."
